questions.question: A scar excision followed by reconstruction with a split skin graft was performed on theforearm of a 28-year-old man. The survival of the graft during the first 48 hours will bemainly dependent on
A patient with a leg injury was treated with a skin graft as shown below. Which of thefollowing statements is false regarding this type of skin graft?

options.A: Degree of contraction is dependant on amount of dermis in graft
options.B: Healing with abnormal pigmentation are more common.
options.D: Meshing grafts improve their ultimate cosmetic appearance1109

questions.explanation: The given image shows a meshed, split-thickness skin graft. Split grafts are meshed to expand thesurface area that can be covered but it does not improve the cosmetic appearance.Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree towhich a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondarycontraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).1117Less dermis also translates into a better chance of graft survival. Thin split grafts have a lowprimary contraction, high secondary contraction, and high reliability of graft take. However, theytend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and poor durability.The image given below shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using ahandheld Humby knife.Type of graftCompositionSplit-thickness graftFull-thickness graftEpidermis + part of the dermEpidermis + full dermisisRelatively poorCosmetic appearanceGraft take/survival High chance of survivalContractionUseLesser primary contraction and more secondary contractionCan cover large areas of defectsGood (texture and pigmentation are better matched)Poor (long healing time and vascularization)More primary contraction and lesser secondary contractionFor areas where least contraction (finger) or best cosmesis(face) is desiredOMARROW

questions.question: A 34-year-old man sustains facial burns and is being planned for reconstruction with a skingraft. Which type of graft should he receive to achieve a better cosmetic appearance andminimal contraction?
questions.explanation: The patient should receive a Wolfe graft to achieve a better cosmetic appearance and minimalcontraction. Wolfe grafts are full-thickness skin grafts that are used for small areas of skinreplacement where good elastic skin that will not contract is required (such as fingers, eyelids, andfacial parts).Option B: Partial-thickness skin grafts or split-thickness grafts are called Thiersch grafts. Theyconsist of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. They tend to heal with abnormal1118pigmentation and result in suboptimal cosmetic appearance.Option C: Composite grafts are grafts that contain skin and fat or skin and cartilage. They areoften taken from the ear margin and useful for rebuilding missing elements of the nose, eyelids,and fingertips.Option D: Blair-Brown grafts are a type of intermediate thickness split skin graft.StructureDonor site locationDonor site woundRecipient siteFull-thickness skin graft (Wol Split thickness skin graft (Thife)Epidermis +complete dermis± fatPost auricular, supra/infra-clavicular.Never axillaryMust be suturedMust be well vascularised. Small areaersche)Epidermis +part of dermisThigh > buttocksRequires only dressing and can be reusedMay be inadequately vascularized. Larger area (achieved by meshing)Graft featuresDurabilityHighPrimary > secondaryContractureUptakeCosmetic resultGoodRequire more care to ensureuptakeLowHigh secondary contractureHigh-reliabilityPoor (abnormal pigmentation)

questions.question: The most common cause of skin graft failure is

options.D: Poor quality of the recipient bed

questions.explanation: The most common cause of skin graft failure is hematoma under the graft, where the blood clot isa barrier to contact of the graft and bed for revascularization.Other causes are shearing or movement of the graft on the bed, infection, poor quality of therecipient bed, and characteristics of the graft itself, such as thickness or vascularity of the donorsite.

questions.question: A 20-year-old lady sustained extensive burns over her left forearm for which a split-thicknessskin graft was planned. During surgery, after obtaining a skin graft from the anterior thigh,the patient became hemodynamically unstable and a transplant to the forearm could not becompleted. What would you do with the harvested graft?

options.A: It must be discarded and fresh graft harvested before repeat surgery
options.B: It can be stored for up to 2-3 days at +4°C in saline
options.C: It can be stored for up to 2-3 weeks at +4°C in saline
options.D: It can be stored for 2-3 months at +4°C in saline

questions.explanation: The harvested graft can be stored at +4°C in refrigeration after wrapping it in a sterile gauze padmoistened with saline. The process of harvesting and storing skin grafts is called skin banking.Skin banks store grafts using various methods. Most commonly preferred is to store the graft forup to 2-3 weeks at +4°C.1119

questions.question: Which of the following is true with respect to a skin graft harvested from the post-auriculararea?
questions.explanation: Graft harvested from the postauricular area is a full-thickness skin graft. As it involves harvestingthe complete dermis donor site needs to be sutured following harvest.Option A: Humby knife is used to harvest split-thickness skin grafts (Thiersche grafts).StructureDonor site locationDonor site woundRecipient siteFull-thickness skin graft (Wol Split thickness skin graft (Thife)Epidermis +complete dermis± fatPost auricular, supra/infra-clavicular.Never axillaryMust be suturedMust be well vascularised. Small areaersche)Epidermis +part of dermisThigh buttocksRequires only dressing and can be reusedMay be inadequately vascularized. Larger area (achieved by meshing)Graft featuresDurabilityHighPrimary > secondaryContractureUptakeCosmetic resultGoodRequire more care to ensureuptakeLowHigh secondary contractureHigh-reliabilityPoor (abnormal pigmentation)

questions.question: A child is being prepared for a Millard's repair as seen in the image. The factors influencingthe development of his condition are all except
questions.explanation: OMARROW1120Vitamin A deficiency during pregnancy is not a factor influencing the development of cleftlip/palate. Millard's repair is the most common surgical repair of cleft lip and is usually performedbetween 3 to 6 months of age.The cause of orofacial clefting is felt to be multifactorial. Factors that likely increase the incidenceof clefting include increased parental age, drug use and infections during pregnancy, and smokingduring pregnancy.

questions.question: The given image shows a forearm flap harvested for the reconstruction of the oral cavity of a45-year-old patient with squamous cell carcinoma. Identify the type of flap.1111
questions.explanation: The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. Fasciocutaneous radial forearm free flap is the mostcommon free flap used in head and neck reconstruction.A flap defines the tongue of tissue whereas a pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with thevascular supply.In a free flap, the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgeryat the new site. Other Eg for free flaps: free fibular flap, DIEP flap (Deep inferior epigastricperforators)Option A: Axial flaps are much longer and are based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus Dorsiflap, TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap.Option B: An islanded flap is that in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk.Option D: A random flap includes three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship towhere the blood supply enters. Eg: V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg, or rhomboid flap.norLonathDVTapGan baDICO PUT ANNOV

questions.question: The flap shown in the picture is which of the following?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a serratus anterior flap. The serratus anterior flap is a highly reliable flapwith a consistently long pedicle. Its anatomy permits coverage of complex wounds. The1121underlying rib can be included as a myoosseous flap to expand the versatility of this flap.Classification of muscle flapsBased on blood supplyMethod of movementBased on compositionRandom flap Unnamed vesselsupplying flapLocal transferRotation flapTransposition flapAdvancementflapSimple FlapCutaneous flapMusculocutaneous FasciocutaneousAxial flapNamed vessel supplying flap.Distant transfer Pedicle flapFree flapComposite flapOsseocutaneous flapSensory flap

questions.question: The image shows a surgical technique used to release Dupuytren's contracture. Which of thefollowing statements is true regarding this?

options.A: It can also be used in the surgical management of keloid scars and contractures
options.B: It reorients the direction of the central wound by 90 degrees
options.C: Triangular flaps created using 60 degrees can lengthen the scar by 50%
options.D: It is a type of local advancement flap

questions.explanation: The image shows a typical example of a Z Plasty.It is a type of transposition flap that incorporates qualities of both advancement and rotationflaps. Z plasty is used for the lengthening of linear scars. It is best used in releasing simplecontractures.Usually, all the limbs are of equal length and ideally, the angle between them is 60°. Twotriangular flaps are raised. Theoretically, a 60-degree angle flap will result in a 75% increase in thelength of the scar and a 90-degree reorientation of central wound.Angles smaller than 60 degrees are easier to transpose but result in less lengthening andrealignment of the scar to less than 90 degrees. Angles larger than 60 degrees should be avoidedbecause the force required to transpose the flaps increases markedly, making the closure of thewound difficult.Relative contraindications to Z-plasty include patients with keloids and hypertrophic scarringtendencies.Z plastyInitial scar/contractureOMARROW1122

questions.question: A truck driver undergoes a Limberg flap operation using a random flap for recurrent pilonidalsinus infections. What is the generally accepted safe and reliable length: width ratio for thistype of flap?
questions.explanation: The Limberg flap is a type of random flap and the safe and reliable length:width ratio for therandom flap 3:1.Random pattern flaps have a blood supply based on small, unnamed blood vessels in thedermal-subdermal plexus, as opposed to the discrete, well described, directional vessels of axialpattern flaps. As random flaps have a variable blood supply, they need an adequate base (width) tosurvive.The rhomboid (Limberg) flap involves creating a skin flap with two opposing angles of 60° and120° at the corners, forming a rhomboid shape positioned directly next to the defect. The designallows the flap to be rotated into the defect, with the donor site closed primarily, ensuringminimal distortion to the surrounding tissues. This method is especially useful in areas like thegluteal region, where complex closure techniques help achieve optimal results.

questions.question: A free flap is used to resurface a tendoachilles defect in a 58-year-old chronic smoker. As afirst-year surgical resident, you are asked to monitor the flap for venous occlusion. Which ofthe following should you be looking out for?
questions.explanation: The first sign of venous occlusion in a free flap is increasing warmth.Clinical signs of arterial and venous compromise in a free flap:Note: Venous and arterial compromise may coexist, and one may lead to the other.Clinical SignArterial CompromisVenous CompromiseeColorBecoming palerIncreasingly reddish or purplishTemperatureBecoming coolerBecoming warmerTissue turgorReducingIncreasingCapillary refill timeBecoming slowerBecoming fasterPinprick bleedingIncreasingly sluggisQuickening (and darkening)h

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the flap given in the image.Skin and fatmoved to chest

options.A: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
options.B: Free TRAM based on superior and inferior epigastric artery
options.C: DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
options.D: Lower Abdominal Fat based inferior epigastric vessels

questions.explanation: The given image showing only skin and fat moved to the chest is suggestive of a deep inferiorepigastric artery perforator flap (DIEP), based on the deep inferior epigastric artery.DIEP is a variant of TRAM flap and free flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest.A microvascular technique is used in which no muscle is taken and the perforating vessels aredissected out.1123As the muscle is spared in DIEP, there is a reduced risk of abdominal wall weakness and itsassociated complications.Other options:Options A and B: The pedicled TRAM flap is based on the superior epigastric artery and the freeTRAM flap is based on superior and inferior epigastric arteries (supercharged TRAM flap);however, the given image depicts a deep inferior epigastric artery flap. In TRAM flaps:The skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest.• It provides good cosmesis and bulk since it has a soft tissue consistency similar to the breast.• Disadvantages include epigastric bulge, partial flap loss, fat necrosis, abdominal wall weakness,and hernias.The given image below shows a TRAM flap:Transverse rectus abdominismyocutaneous flapTransverserectusabdominismuscleSkin, Fat andmusclemoved to chestOMARROW

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman who underwent a skin-sparing mastectomy a year ago has returned toyour clinic to discuss her options for breast reconstruction. All of the following are options toconsider except:1114

options.A: A TRAM flap provides the best cosmetic result than LD flap
options.B: An LD flap provides adequate bulk of breast tissue
options.C: Reconstruction may be delayed or immediate
options.D: Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants

questions.explanation: An LD flap does not provide the bulk required and is usually used along with an implant. It isbased on the thoracodorsal pedicle. It is an axial flap.1124Latissimus dorsi flapLatissimusdorsi-muscle-Skin, fat andmusclemoved to chestOMARROWTransverse rectus abdominus myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on superior epigastric orinferior epigastric or both (supercharged TRAM). Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest. Itprovides good cosmesis and bulk. An implant is usually not required. Since the rectus abdominismuscle is excised in the procedure, it can lead to abdominal wall weakness and hernias.Transverse rectus abdominismyocutaneous flapTransverserectusabdominismuscleSkin, Fat andmusclemoved to chestOMARROWThe timing of reconstruction may be immediate or delayed. Impediments to immediatereconstruction include insufficient theatre time and a lack of experienced reconstructive surgeons.In addition, the patient is likely to need post-op radiotherapy, then a delayed reconstruction usinga flap often gives better results.The easiest type of reconstruction is using a silicone gel implant under the pectoralis majormuscle. Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man with osteosarcoma of the mandibular ramus is planned for resection andreconstruction with a flap. The flap used most commonly in mandibular reconstruction isbased on which of the following vascular structures?
questions.explanation: 1125The most commonly used osseous flap for mandibular reconstruction is the fibular free flap. Thefibular free flap is based on the peroneal artery and vein, and the blood supply to the foot shouldbe investigated before harvesting this flap.Common flaps and their usesThe free fibular flap may also be used to correct the Andy Gump deformity. It is an anteriormandibular defect that creates the appearance of an absent chin and lower lip and severelyretrognathic lower jaw, which is named after a character in an early 20th-century comic strip.Name of flapPectoralis major myocutaneousDeltopectoralRadial forearmAbbe EstlanderUseHead and neck reconstructionBased onPectoral branch of thoracoacromial arteryInternal mammary vesselsnHead and neck reconstructioHead and neck reconstructioRadial vesselsnMidline lip and angle of mouth reconstructionLabial vesselsKarapandzicTransverse rectus abdominismyocutaneous (TRAM)Free TRAMLattisimus dorsiLip reconstructionBreast reconstruction (most commonly used flap)Breast reconstructionBreast reconstructionDeep inferior epigastric arterBreast reconstructionMandibular reconstruction Andy Gump deformityyFree fibularLabial vesselsSuperior epigastric vesselsInferior epigastric vesselsThoracodorsal vesselsDeep inferior epigastric artery perforatorsPeroneal vessels1126

questions.question: A 56-year-old patient suffering from alcoholic cirrhosis receives a healthy liver from hisbiological son. What is this type of transplant known as?
questions.explanation: Transplant of an organ/tissue from a son to a parent is an example of an allograft.An allograft is transplant of cells/tissues/organs from a genetically non-identical donor of the samespecies.Isografts are allografts in which cells/tissues/organs are transplanted from a donor to a geneticallyidentical recipient. (monozygotic twins)

questions.question: What incision would you make to excise a lesion on the bridge of the nose, in order to causeminimal scarring?
questions.explanation: A horizontal incision should be taken as the relaxed skin tension lines (Borge's lines) at the bridgeof the nose are horizontal.Aligning a surgical incision or excision with skin tension lines results in minimal tension acrossthe closure of the defect. This leads to optimal scar formation and minimizes wound contraction.Skin tension lines reflect internal tension within the skin and are produced by the parallelalignment of connective tissue of the dermis. Several different skin tension lines have beendescribed. Borge's lines which are also called relaxed skin tension lines are most useful to guidesurgical incision. These are often confused with Langer's lines.Langer's lines, also called cleavage lines are topological lines drawn based on the shape of woundson cadavers. These were not intended as a guide for surgical incisions and they do not alwayscorrespond to the best orientation of skin tension and often run perpendicular to skin folds. Onthe face, these two sets of lines often run at right angles to one another.

questions.question: 1115A plastic surgeon performs an upper eyelid reconstruction using a tarsoconjunctival flap for apatient who underwent a sebaceous gland carcinoma excision. What is the maximum tissueloss for which a primary repair would have sufficed?
questions.explanation: Borge's relaxed skin tension linesLanger's linesOMARROW1127Defects comprising <25% of the upper eyelid can generally be closed primarily in pentagonalapproximating fashion.For defects involving 25-50% of the upper eyelid, lateral canthotomy and cantholysis can beperformed.Defects more than 50% need proper flap cover.

questions.question: A mother brings her 3-week-old baby to the pediatrics OPD, with a lesion on his abdomenwhich has been growing in size since birth. On examination, the lesion is red, nodular, andblanches on pressure. What is the next step in management?

options.A: Local resection with carbon dioxide laser
options.B: En bloc excision with skin grafting

questions.explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of infantile hemangioma. Only monitoring of the lesion isrequired as in 50% of cases, complete involution is seen by 5 years of age.Hemangioma growth frequently peaks before the first year, and then the lesions enter theinvoluting phase. The involution phase begins in 50% of children by 5 years of age and in 70% by7 years of age. It continues until 10 years of age.Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining tothe location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to large hemangioma over eyelid).Treatment options include:• Beta blockers oral propranolol•-Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids• Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine for steroid-resistant lesions-• Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser1128
